EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.0 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy
It is the Policy of Tempur Production USA, Inc. to prevent accidental release of chemicals by managing the receiving, the storage and transfer of chemicals in a manner that minimizes the risk of accidental release.  Tempur Production USA, Inc. Emergency  Response Policy has been developed to protect Human Health and the Environment in the event of an accidental chemical release.


2.0 Facility and Regulated Substances Handled
Tempur Production USA, Inc. is a newly constructed Polyurethane Foam Manufacturing facility located at 4700 Boone Trail Road South, Duffield Virginia, 24244.   The facility will begin the production of foam products during the second quarter of 2001.  The facility has recognized the need to comply with 40 CFR Part 68, EPA Risk Management Program.  

The Tempur Production USA facility's Risk Management Plan (RMP) has been developed based upon the List of Regulated Toxic Substances and Threshold Quantities for Accidental Release Prevention.  Those chemical(s) exceeding the Threshold Quantities include:

Process 1) Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) (unspecified isomer) 
CAS # 26471-62-1  (Threshold Planning Quantity = 10,000 pounds)

TDI at the Duffield facility will be offloaded, stored, and utilized within the 300,000 SF manufacturing site.  Vessel storage of TDI will consist of 6 tanks with each tank having a capacity of 6,600 gallons (67,000 pounds) with a total aggregate storage capacity of 402,000 pounds contained within a increased fire rated structure located within the primary facility.  The TDI storage area is encompassed by a secondary containment structure capable of capturing releases in excess of the capacity of the largest vessel.  The secondary containment structure is encompassed by tertiary containment area capable of capturing the capacity of all of the TDI within the largest vessel.   The enclosed off loading bay is immediately adjacent

to the storage vessel room and has an independent capture trench capable of holding in excess of the maximum volume of TDI to be delivered via DOT tanker truck.  No external heat is added during the process and the TDI is stable at the ambient temperature ranges.

The Risk Management Plan identifies one (1) regulated process with the potential for toxic liquid release.  No processes have been identified that involve materials from the list of Regulated Flammable Substances and Threshold Quantities for Accidental Release Prevention.  





3.0 Worst Case Scenario
Based upon the worst case scenario of a catastrophic vessel failure that resulted in an instantaneous release of 100% of the largest tank contents into the secondary containment:

Secondary Containment area      130 square meters
Liquid Temperature                      77 degrees F
Release rate to outside air           0.0118 pounds per minute
Total evaporation time                  6370000 minutes
Topography                                 Rural Surroundings
(note: RMP*Submit electronic filing software did not permit entering a release rate to outside air of less than 1 pound per minute nor a total evaporation time of greater than 60 minutes)

The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.1 miles was calculated by RMP*Comp Version 1.04 based upon a toxic endpoint value of 0.0070 mg/l in air.  Based upon the distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.1 miles in this rural community, the facility has recognized there to be public receptors along the fringe boundary of the endpoint radius.  Given the close proximity to the endpoint distance of these public receptors, the facility has elected to file the RMP within the Program 2 protocol.  While it is highly unlikely the worst-case scenario would occur, it is even more unlikely for impact to occur to these public receptors.  The public receptors along the fringe boundary of the endpoint distance radius include small commercial businesses in the immediate vicinity

of the facility.  Located at greater distances from the endpoint boundary are public highways, commercial businesses, a federal post office, residences, and an elementary school.     


4.0 A Based upon an alternate worse case scenario of a transfer system failure that resulted in an instantaneous release of 100% of the largest tank into the transfer piping trench:

    Secondary Containment Area        60 square meters
    Liquid Temp                                    77 degrees F
    Release Rate to Outside Air           <0.0118 pounds per min.

The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the alternate worse case scenario is less than 0.1 miles as calculated by RMP* Comp Version 1.04 based upon a toxic endpoint value of 0.0070 mg/l.

Based upon the distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.1 miles in this rural community, the facility has recognized there to be public receptors along the fringe boundary of the endpoint radius.  Given the close proximity to the endpoint of the public receptors, the facility has elected to file the RMP within the Program 2 protocol.  While it is unlikely the alternate worse case scenario would occur, it is even more unlikely for impact to occur to these public receptors.  The public receptors along the fringe boundary of the endpoint distance radius include small commercial businesses in the immediate vicinity of the facility.  Located at greater distances from the endpoint boundary are public highways, commercial businesses, a federal post office, residences, and an elementary school.     



5.0 General Accidental Release Prevention Program
The General Accidental Release Prevention Program has 8 key elements to insure adequate measures are developed and implemented that safeguard against accidental release.  These include:

?    The compiling and maintaining of up-to-date Safety Information.
?    The completion of a Hazard Review.
?    The development and implementation of appropriate operating procedures.
?    Adequate training of process employees.

?    Implementation of Preventative Maintenance Program.
?    Compliance audits scheduled every three years.
?    Develop procedures to coordinate incident investigations.

In addition to the programs and procedures listed above the facility process has been designed with accidental chemical release prevention as a priority.  Active and passive mitigation steps have been integrated into the process to provide failsafe measures that are designed to intercede and prevent an accidental release in the event abnormal circumstances occur.  These include:
?    Receiving 
-    Administrative verification of chemical delivery.
?    Bulk Transfer 
-     Operator present during offloading.
-    Tempur employee present during offloading.
-    Emergency spill trench at tanker truck.
-    Enclosed offloading structure.
-    Offloading manifold inside secondary containment.
-    Each chemical has a physically different connection.
-    Closed loop vessel and tanker vent system.
-    Vessel fill gauges and alarms.
-    Dead man switch during offloading.
-    Transfer pump
-    Closed loop pressure relief system
-    Vessels and associated piping are inspected on a daily, weekly and monthly basis.
-    Secondary containment surrounding TDI vessels.
-    Tertiary containment surrounding secondary containment.
-    Vessel storage in separate room within the facility.

?    Manufacturing
-    Computer controlled manufacturing process transfer
-    Rates
-    Volumes
-    Levels
-    Computer controlled Alarms and stops if abnormal circumstances are monitored.
-    Continuous TDI area monitoring sensors in tank farm area.



6.0 Five Year Accident History
This is a new facility; therefore there is no accident history to report.  However, this facility is comparable to facilities operated outside the USA by the same parent company.  No off-site accidents have occurred at those facilities within the last five years.




7.0 Emergency Response Program
An Emergency Response Plan has been developed and will be maintained for the facility.  The plan includes:

?    Procedure

s for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases.
?    Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures.
?    Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release of a regulated substance.
?    Procedure for the use of emergency response equipment, inspection, testing, and maintenance.
?    Employee training.
?    Procedures for review and update the Emergency Response Plan.

In addition to those policies and procedures identified herein, the facility has met with the Scott County, Virginia Department of Emergency Management Coordination and his staff to discuss emergency preparation and emergency response.  The facility management will continue to work closely with the local emergency response teams in planning for potential chemical emergencies.


8.0 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Weekly safety inspections will be conducted to identify potentially unsafe acts or conditions within the facility.  Corrective measures will be implemented to resolve identified safety concerns in a manner that protects employee health, reduces the risk of accidental chemical discharge and is protective of the natural environment
